Award.AwardTitle: "CSEDI: From fine to global scales: Integrated studies of the structure, dynamics, and mineral physics of the lower mantle"
Award.AbstractNarration:
The solid earth, the earth excluding the oceans and atmosphere, is a giant heat engine responsible for not only continental drift and plate tectonics, but also geological hazards (especially those from giant earthquakes) and for the formation of mineral and hydrocarbon resources. The purpose of this research is to better understand how this heat engine works by focusing on the earth's lower mantle. The lower mantle is the largest region of the planet by volume and the heat sources and physical processes there play a critical role in determining how the heat engine works. In this project, we will take a cooperative approach in which we will understand the basic material properties of earth materials under extreme pressures and temperatures; incorporate those experimental results into three-dimensional simulations of the earth's interior; and then test the predictions of both approaches with detailed studies of seismic waves passing through the earth's deep interior. We believe that there are three areas in which our work will have broad impact. First, our specialized work on the lower mantle is of broad interest to the scientific community because it improves our understanding of how the earth works as an interconnected, dynamic system. Second, we will partially support and mentor three Caltech graduate students in the Seismology Lab. and thereby contribute to the training of the next generation of scientists in the U.S. Third, our multidisciplinary approach will allow our students to become leaders in the internationally competitive field of global geophysics.

Seismologists have revealed that the mantle side of the core mantle boundary (D") is extraordinarily complex with a myriad of fine structure (e.g. ~10 km to a few 100 km's). Thermal and chemical heterogeneity, solid-solid phase transitions, and melting within the lower mantle are probably all required in order to explain observed structure and suggest that the lower boundary of the mantle is as complex as the continental crust. Understanding the origin of the fine scale structure of the lower mantle, in general, and D", in particular, is key toward understanding how the solid Earth works as a globally interconnected system. In order to better understand this region from the different means available, this work will involve collaboration between a seismologist, a geodynamist, and an experimental mineral physicist.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our work concerns the mantle, the solid region of the earth between the base of the crust and the top of the fluid core as much of the heat and dynamics ultimately driving continental drift and plate tectonics reside in the lower part of this region, called the lower mantle.  The boundary between the core and mantle has a fundamental influence on the magnetic field, the cooling of the planet, and volcanism at the Earth's surface.  Through seismic observations, we have found that the mantle side of this boundary (D" in the technical literature) is quite complex with a myriad of fine structure (e.g. ~10 km to a few 100 km's).  We suspect that thermal and chemical heterogeneity, solid-solid phase transitions, crystal fabric, and melting within the lower mantle are probably all required in order to explain this observed fine structure, which suggests that the lower boundary of the mantle is nearly as complex as the earth’s surface. Our research uses and merges results and methods from three distinct areas of the earth sciences. First, we use seismic observations to map out structure and then test ideas for deep earth processes. Second, we study in the laboratory the material properties of candidate minerals under the extreme conditions of the deep interior. Finally, we develop computer models to integrate the seismic observations and experimental results while developing new testable predictions of deep earth dynamics.

 

Several key measurements as a function of pressure and temperature, including density, sound velocity, and chemical composition, were made to map seismic observations to chemical composition, while informing geodynamic models. We performed measurements on various iron rich and iron poor phases of (Mg,Fe)O and then constrained the effect of iron on the density and elasticity of these phases. Previously, Ph.D. student June Wicks discovered that the sound velocities of iron-rich (Mg,Fe)O at high-pressure remain extraordinarily low and suggests that this phase is consistent with wave speed reductions and density increases inferred for ultralow-velocity zones (ULVZs). ULVZs are amongst the most anomalous structures in the deep earth and have long been thought of as magma chamber-like, but resting on the core mantle boundary. We explored these hypotheses by simulating convection to deduce the stability and morphology of such chemically distinct structures. The density largely dictates ULVZ shape and the initial thickness of the chemically distinct layer controls its size. We found that the seismic data are compatible with a solid-state origin for ULVZs. Our work has called into question the long-standing fluid phase origin of ULVZs.

 

Using a numerical model we explored the consequences of the density change caused by the iron spin transition in ferropericlase on the style and vigor of mantle convection. The transition from high to low spin introduces a net spin-state driving density difference for both upwellings and downwellings. We found that spin-buoyancy dominantly enhances the positive thermal buoyancy of plumes. Convective heat transport is more effective and temperatures in the core-mantle boundary region are reduced.

 

We studied the details of the largest structures in the lower mantle, the so-called superplumes below Africa and the western Pacific. Using new waveform imaging, we discovered a narrow plume?like feature emitting from the top of the large African super-plume. With a new processing technique, we located a relatively jagged, sloping wall 1000 km high with low velocities near the structures basal edge. Our work suggests that the plume’s diameter is less than 150 km and consistent with an isochemical, low?viscosity plume conduit.
